_prev_prog_2.Description: Central Farm Service (CFS) retains two OUTSIDE contractors who utilizes their own equipment for the production of ammoniated polyphosphate liquids.  CFS is NOT involved in the conversion production process.  This Program Prevention Description pertains to contractor, Blick's Phosphate Conversions LLC (Blick?s).  Blick's has provided CFS with documentation supporting a mechanical integrity program is in place. Blick?s owns and operates a mobile pipe reactor (MPR)  The MPR is used to manufacture ammonium polyphosphate fertilzer (e.g. 10-34-0) for Central Farm Service (CFS) for retail sale to our customers.  Blick's brings the mobile unit on site to complete the conversion process for CFS.   The critical process safety parameters are as follows:  Pressure:  350 psig.  The 3? ammonia hoses are rated for a maximum working pressure of 350 psig with a burst pressure of 1,750 psig.  The valves and pumps on the system are rated for a maximum working pressure of 400 psig.  The Contractor monitors process pressures during the operation of the process and they are kept well below 350 psi.  Additionally, there is a safety relief valve on the non-contact ammonia/product heat exchanger that is set to discharge at 250 psig, and the ammonia pump has a bypass valve with a differential pressure (between suction and discharge) setting of 150 psig.  Thus, pressure should be relived to either the atmosphere or the ammonia source tank if there is a sudden spike in system downstream of the ammonia transfer pump.  Additional accident prevention program details relative to ensuring water and acid supplies are correct along with other details of the covered process are carried with the T-Reactor.  Blick's has also provided CFS a copy of their Emergency Response and Contingency Plan, which details their operating procedures, training programs, safe work practices, etc. CFS also has their own Emergency Action Plan, Response Plan and other safety procedures and policies in place.

_prev_prog_2.Description:
Central Farm Service (CFS) retains two OUTSIDE contractors who utilizes their own unit to manufacture ammonium polyphosphate fertilizer. CFS is not involved in the manufacturing or conversion process.  This Program Description and information contained in this Program relates to contractor Mears Fertilizer, Inc. (hereinafter Contractor). Contractor has provided CFS with documentation to support a mechanical integrity program is in place along with written operating procedures, safe work procedures, emergency action plan, and a training program for the conversion process.  Additionally, CFS has their own Emergency Action Plan, ER Response Plan and other safety procedures and policies in place.  The involved contractor reports that the following safeties to the process are in place:  

An audible and visual alarm system, which will warn if the pump or over pressurization of equipment occurs.  Fisher N-550 Emergency Shut-off Valves are installed at discharge of source and at the ammonia pump, and pneumatically held open during use, and they are capable of remote closure.  The ammonia hose used between source and pump, as well as that used for bypass, is FMH-22 double-braided, corrugated 316L SS to avoid potential rupture between these critical connections.  A standard Fisher ammonia regulator is used at the pump, pressure controlled, to bypass any excess ammonia to the suction side of the pump.  A standard ammonia backcheck valve is used on the input line at the Mix Unit to prevent ammonia loss in case of hose rupture.  Pressure relief valves for the ammonia system are re-certified annually by an outside vendor.  These added safeties have proven effective in avoiding potential releases as evidenced by the Contractor?s safety record.

_accidents.ED_Other: ON-SITE soil excavation of approx 14 yards was overseen by MN Dept. of Ag
_accidents.CI_OtherType: Additional pull away devices and check valves installed by Contractor

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: MN Department of Agricultural Administrative Rules

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility:



Management and employees of Central Farm Service, Clarks Grove, MN location (hereinafter CFS), are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the onsite contractor manufacturing the liquid fertilizer, the local fire department, and other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to the public and the environment.



2. Facility Information:



CFS periodically retains two OUTSIDE contractors who utilize a mobile unit and manufacture ammonium polyphosphate fertilizer (e.g. 10-34-0). CFS is neither involved in the manufacturing/conversion process, nor does CFS own the involved equipment. Raw materials used in the conversion process include anhydrous ammonia, phosphoric acid and water. The anhydrous ammonia used in the conversion process is brought onto the facility in a semi transport/semi-tanker, or railcar. The anhydrous ammonia is on site temporarily during the conversion process:  this facility has no permanent storage of anhydrous ammonia.  Rather, it is transferred from the semi-tanker or railcar directly to the contractor's process equipment where the manufacturing process takes place immediately.  Therefore, this RMP is filed as a Predictive Filing and CFS is covered under RMP Level 2.  When the contractor's portable conversion equipment arrives on site, the CFS site RMP Level 2 is meshed with the contractor's PSM Program Level 3 to satisfy regulatory requirements during the manufacturing/conversion process. 



3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:



The facility has implemented Minnesota Dept. of Agriculture Administrative Rules, and the Standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Ha

ndling of Anhydrous Ammonia. CFS employees are not involved with the conversion process-the contractor utilizes their own employees who they train to safely operate their equipment. Both contractors have provided CFS with documentation to support a mechanical integrity program and written operating procedures are in place, along with safe work procedures, emergency action plan, and a training program for the covered process.  



4. The Five-year Accident History:  

One accidental release of anhydrous ammonia occurred on December 15, 2014 during the conversion process by one of the outside contractors:  it involved the accidental opening of a hose valve by a contractor employee.  CFS was not involved with the accident, and did not own the involved semi-tanker or the conversion equipment.  Neither CFS, nor its employees caused or contributed to the release.  However, because the release occurred at the facility, the release is being identified as part of this RMP.  Investigation of the incident began immediately, which also included the Minnesota Department of Agriculture's involvement.  The required investigative report pursuant to 40 CFR 68.60 has also been completed.



5. The Emergency Response Program:



CFS has:

a. A written emergency action plan in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38 and a emergency response program in accordance with 40 CFR 68.95.  The next annual emergency action plan and NH3 emergency response program training is scheduled for July 2018.  Additional emergency training is also provided throughout the year at various training sessions, including but not limited to training held every fall on anhydrous ammonia. In the event of an accidental release during the conversion process, CFS employees are trained to call 911; and follow all established evacuation and emergency procedures set forth in their EAP and IRP as well as follow all contractor emergency procedures.  



b. Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning

and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)



c. Coordinated with local emergency responders.



d. A Safety Data Sheet for anhydrous ammonia as part of their emergency response plan information for quick access and reference. 



e. A Minnesota AWAIR ( A Workplace Accident and Injury Reduction) program in place and is committed to a safe working environment as well as protection of the community in which we operate.



The Conversion Contractors have provided CFS with multiple documents confirming they meet the requirements of the fourteen (14) elements under 29 CFR Part 1910 Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals and 40 CFR Part 68, Section 112.  Their portable or mobile mix units carry multiple operating documents to ensure safe operation of their reactor, as well as Emergency Action Plans and/or Field Emergency Procedure/Plans.  



6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  CFS is continuing to work with the conversion companies to ensure all safety and compliance measures as required are taken prior to beginning the conversion process.
